occurrences.line_text: Feare to his first amazment, staring wide
The which him into great amaz'ment droue,
The Amazon huge riuer now found trew?
That a proud Amazon did late defy
How hight that Amazon (sayd Artegall?)
And th'Amazon, as best it likt her selfe to dight.
Then tooke the Amazon this noble knight,
During which time, the warlike Amazon,
For seeking thus to salue the Amazon,
Which when the cruell Amazon perceiued,
The warlike Amazon out of her bowre did peepe.
Full fiercely layde the Amazon about,
Whom that proud Amazon subdewed had,
Vnto the dwelling of that Amazone.
But ere they reared hand, the Amazone
Of Amazons, whom Pyrrhus did destroy,
Of warlike Amazons, which doe possesse the same.
And Queene of Amazons, in armes well tride,
There bound t'obay that Amazons proud law,
With which those Amazons his loue still craued,
Vnto the land of Amazons, as she was bent.
Gold, amber, yuorie, perles, owches, rings,
That was Ambition, rash desire to sty,
Through proud ambition, against her rebeld,
And through ambition downe themselues doe driue
Now loath great Lordship and ambition;
As when two rams stird with ambitious pride,
Ambitious Sylla, and sterne Marius,
Then his ambitious sonnes vnto them twaine
Seruing th'ambitious will of Augustine,
O Sacred hunger of ambitious mindes,
Hard is to teach an old horse amble trew.
An ambling Colt, that is his proper owne:
Ambrose and Vther did ripe years attaine,
And were with sweet Ambrosia all besprinckled light.
The which ambrosiall odours from them threw,
And with ambrosiall kisses bathe his eyes;
Deawd with ambrosiall kisses, by thee gotten
The which ambrosiall odours forth did throw
And coosen vnto king Ambrosius:
Out of their ambush broke, and gan him to inuade.
With many moe lay in ambushment there,
High God be witnesse, that I guiltlesse ame.
Must first begin, and well her amenage:
By faithfull seruice, and meet amenance,
In braue aray and goodly amenance,
Th'enchaunter by his armes and amenaunce,
Without regard of grace, or comely amenaunce.
Yet no'te the same amend, ne yet withstond,
And their decayed kingdomes shall amend:
That ryde he could not, till his hurts he did amend.
And thought in mind it shortly to amend:
Good hart in euils doth the euils much amend.
It euer to amend: ne maruaile ought;
And my flockes father daily doth amend it.
Which had so great dismay so well amended,
That his scarse diet somewhat was amended,
By meanes whereof, that mote not be amended,
Amendment readie still at hand did wayt,
Or make you good amendment for the same:
All wrongs haue mends, but no amends of shame.
Till he had made amends, and full restore
And after promist large amends to make.
They drew their swords, in mind to make amends
Yeeld for amends my selfe yours euermore,
Amends may for the trespasse soone be made,
Aie me, how could her loue make half amends therefore.
And all that now America men call:
A sweet regard, and amiable grace,
For she was full of amiable grace,
But therein sate an amiable Dame,
Whom when I saw with amiable grace
Her wand did moue with amiable looke,
A goodly youth of amiable grace,
Amid the thickest woods. The Champion stout
Amid the bowels of the earth full steepe,
Amid the Ocean waues, ne was it sought
Amid th'AegÃ¦an sea long time did stray,
Now when amid the thickest woods they were,
Tossing them like a boate amid the mayne,
Amid their shields, with so huge might and maine,
And farre away, amid their rakehell bands,
Then did my younger brother Amidas
Now tell me Amidas, if that ye may,
So Amidas, the land was yours first hight,
Both Amidas and Philtra were displeased:
He to his study goes, and there amiddes
His speare amids her sun-broad shield arriued;
And still amidst her rayling, she did pray,
Amidst a flocke of Damzels fresh and gay,
Amidst them all he in a chaire was set,
Amidst the bridale feast, whilest euery man
Whilest thus amidst the billowes beating of her
Amidst a ring most richly well enchaced,
But that fourth Mayd, which there amidst the[m] traced,
Me seemes I see Amintas wretched fate,
Or wonted feare of doing ought amis,
Whither the soules do fly of men, that liue amis.
In stead of foe to wound my friend amis?
Arayd in habit blacke, and amis thin,
How that same knight should do so foule amis,
The cursed land where many wend amis,
Where ease abounds, yt's eath to doe amis;
And oft when things were lost, or laid amis,
Of her fond fauorites so nam'd amis:
If ought amis her liking may abuse:
And certes seemes bestowed not amis:
So be ye pleasd to pardon all amis.
Most did she thinke, but most she thought amis,
To shew that clemence oft in things amis,
Ne none can backe returne, that once are gone amis.
And how he slew with glauncing dart amisse
He wist himselfe amisse, and angry said;
And mou'd amisse with massie mucks vnmeet regard.
Faynd to alight, something amisse to mend;
The meed of them that loue, and do not liue amisse.
Which punish wicked men, that walke amisse:
Which on her waited, things amisse to mend,
And being once amisse growes daily wourse and wourse.
And all this world with them amisse doe moue,
But most is Mars amisse of all the rest,
T'amend what was amisse, and put in right aray.
But louely peace, and gentle amitie,
And would as Ammons sonne be magnifide,
He chose an halter from among the rest,
Of those that roome was full, and them among
And all mens eyes and hearts, which there among
Was in the middest plast among them all;
Such heauenly iustice doth among them raine,
And still among most bitter wordes they spake,
By reason of the streight, and rocks among,
And mixed threats among, and much vnto her vowed.
In much delight, and many ioyes among,
Amongst these mighty men were wemen mixt,
More fit amongst blacke fiendes, then men to haue his place.
And them amongst, some were of burnisht gold,
Amongst her watry sisters by a pond,
That creeping close, amongst the hiues to reare
Amongst all which was none more faire then shee,
Amongst the rest there was a iolly knight,
Amongst fraile men, that many a publike state
The which amongst the Lapithees befell,
Amongst those famous ympes of Greece, did take
Amongst her louers, and great quarrels wrought,
Amongst them all this end he did decree;
Amongst those knights there were three brethren bold,
And neuer discord did amongst them fall;
Before that they in blisse amongst the Gods were plaste.
Amongst her teares immixing prayers meeke,
Amongst the which they told, as then befell,
There he amongst them cruell hauocke makes;
That did amongst the troupes so tyrannize;
Amongst the lesser starres in euening cleare.
Amongst the rest with boastfull vaine pretense
So peace being confirm'd amongst them all,
Amongst the rest a iewell rich he found,
Amongst the rest she chaunced there to see
Amongst the rest, that Squire of low degree
And purchase me some place amongst the best.
Amongst the rest some one through loues constrayning,
With siluer streames amongst the linnen stray'd;
Oft-times amo[n]gst the wanton Nymphs to sport and toy.
And there amongst the rest, the mother was
Amongst the rest, was faire Cymodoce,
Did march amongst the many all the way:
Amongst his peres playing his childish sport:
Tempred with Adamant amongst the same,
Amongst the flags and couert round about.
So farre he past amongst his enemies band,
So cruell doale amongst her maides dauide,
He with his yron flaile amongst them thondred,
Amongst the which she causd his warlike armes
Amongst them all she placed him most low,
Now she deuiz'd amongst the warlike rout
Amongst loose Ladies, lapped in delight:
Amongst the yron hookes and graples keene,
Glistring like gold, amongst the plights enrold,
And them amongst, her glorie to commend,
Amongst the rest, which in that space befell,
Amongst the which then fortuned to bee
And like a Lion wood amongst them fares,
Amongst all Knights he blotted was with blame,
To throw amongst the good, which others had disprad.
A rauenous Wolfe amongst the scattered flockes.
Amongst them all growes not a fayrer flowre,
That in these woods amongst the Nymphs dost wonne,
For loue amongst the woodie Gods to dwell;)
To hunt the saluage chace amongst my peres,
And borne great sway in armes amongst his peares:
Amongst wilde beastes in desert forrests bred,
Amongst so many foes, whom sure he thought
They made amongst them selues; but when her face
The which amongst them they in peeces teare,
Amongst themselues, and did their labours share,
That I disdain'd amongst mine equall peares
Amongst that rusticke rout in all his deeds,
For courtesie amongst the rudest breds
And set his rest amongst the rusticke sort,
Amongst poore hyndes, in hils, in woods, in dales,
Amongst the rest, the which they then did pray,
That worldly chaunces doe amongst them cast,
Amongst those theeues, which her in bondage strong
Thus as they words amongst them multiply,
Of cryes and clamors, which amongst them past,
So did he fly amongst them here and there,
And them amongst were mingled here and there,
At her so pitteous cry was much amoou'd
Of Amoret is told.
Why then is Amoret in caytiue band,
Faire Amoret must dwell in wicked chaines,
Amoret, through charmes decayd.
But most faire Amoret, whose gentle spright
Fayre Britomart saues Amoret,
For Amoret right fearefull was and faint,
That fairest Amoret was his by right,
Whom she requir'd, that first fayre Amoret
And eke fayre Amoret now freed from feare,
I saw him haue your Amoret at will,
Her louely Amoret did open shew;
Till that at last the gentle Amoret
Ne her owne Amoret forgoe so light
But taking with her louely Amoret,
Was Amoret, companion of her care:
Desiring of his Amoret to heare
My Amoret, sith you her freed fro thence,
With whom she went to seeke faire Amoret,
Amoret rapt by greedie lust
The louely Amoret, whose gentle hart
The whiles faire Amoret, of nought affeard,
Ah sad AEmylia (then sayd Amoret,)
Which when as fearefull Amoret perceiued,
She left the gentle Squire with Amoret:
AEmylia and Amoret abode,
Of Amoret, so neare vnto decay,
Faire Amoret, that scarcely she could ryde;
Faire Amoret, whom Fortune by bequest
Of vertuous Amoret:
VVhose euer be the shield, faire Amoret be his.
That same was fayrest Amoret in place,
Then that of Amorets hart-binding chaine,
Faire Amoretta in the second place:
Her Amoretta cald, to comfort her dismayd.
Working belgards, and amorous retrate,
To steale a snatch of amorous conceipt,
Grew pensiue through that amorous discourse,
And otherwhiles with amorous delights,
Long were to tell the amorous assayes,
And him beside marcht amorous Desyre,
To bath in ioy and amorous desire,
That she well pleased was thence to amoue him farre.
Yet sore amoued with so puissant push,
Therewith amoued from his sober mood,
Yet none of all them her thereof amoued,
Out of the goodly heauen amoued quight,
Tho stooping downe she him amoued light;
And him amoues with speaches seeming fit:
And sad remembraunce now the Prince amoues,
So vp he rose, and thence amounted streight.
And in Amours the passing houres to spend,
The daughter of Amphisa, who by race
Faire Amphitrite, most diuinely faire,
Ioyous Thalia, goodly Amphitrite,
Fro me do flow into an ample flood,
That stretcht it selfe into an ample plaine,
More ample spirit, then hitherto was wount,
And eke that ample Pit, yet farre renownd,
And ample volume, that doth far excead
The which into an ample lauer fell,
Her ample shield she threw before her face,
And all the people in that ample hous
The Dwarfe cald at the doore of Amyas,
Enfolding said, And liues yet Amyas?
And angry Ioue an hideous storme of raine
The forward footing for an hidden shade:
High on an hill, his flocke to vewen wide,
An aged Sire, in long blacke weedes yclad,
There was an holy Chappell edifyde,
He strowd an Aue-Mary after and before.
Borne the sole daughter of an Emperour,
And lost an old foe, that did you molest:
Better new friend then an old foe is said.
Vnto an hill; from whence when she him spyde,
A dreadfull Dragon with an hideous trayne,
Like to an holy Monck, the seruice to begin.
When such an one had guiding of the way,
And on his head an yuie girland had,
And in his lap an heape of coine he told;
An hatefull Snake, the which his taile vptyes
Whereas an errant knight in armes ycled,
And for his sake haue felt full many an heauie stowre.
By that same hole an entrance darke and bace
And Sisyphus an huge round stone did reele
Against an hill, ne might from labour lin;
Into an Oxe he was transform'd of yore:
An hidden rocke escaped hath vnwares,
And with an yuie twyne his wast is girt about.
An hideous Geant horrible and hye,
An yron brest, and backe of scaly bras,
Like to an Almond tree ymounted hye
An huge great Dragon horrible in sight,
Till all vnweeting, an Enchaunter bad
Then tooke that Squire an horne of bugle small,
And trembling with strange feare, did like an earthquake show.
An heard of Bulles, whom kindly rage doth sting,
That downe he tombled; as an aged tree,
Was nothing left, but like an emptie bladder was.
An old old man, with beard as white as snow,
An Altare, caru'd with cunning imagery,
At last he came vnto an yron doore,
Therewith an hollow, dreary, murmuring voyce
And shame t'auenge so weake an enimy;
For one of them was like an Eagles claw,
An armed knight towards them gallop fast,
About his neck an hempen rope he weares,
His dwelling has, low in an hollow caue,
And made an open passage for the gushing flood.
From highest heauen, and beares an equall eye?
He chose an halter from among the rest,
There was an auntient house not farre away,
He was an aged syre, all hory gray,
Strange thing it is an errant knight to see
And bitter Penance with an yron whip,
Of turtle doues, she sitting in an yuorie chaire.
An auncient matrone she to her does call,
Eftsoones vnto an holy Hospitall,
Forth to an hill, that was both steepe and hy;
Wherein an aged holy man did lye,
The mossy braunches of an Oke halfe ded.
And in an heaped furrow did thee hyde,
And to an hill her selfe with draw aside,
Which as an Eagle, seeing pray appeare,
For as the clashing of an Armour bright,
So downe he fell, as an huge rockie clift,
So downe he fell, and like an heaped mountaine lay.
During the which there was an heauenly noise
Like as it had bene many an Angels voice,
Of some th'aboundance of an idle braine
That no'te without an hound fine footing trace.
He was an Elfin borne of noble state,
So now he Guyon guides an vncouth way
The dead corse of an armed knight was spred,
Palmer (quoth he) death is an equall doome
And be for all chast Dames an endlesse moniment.
An heauie load himselfe did lightly reare,
It was an auncient worke of antique fame,
Was hight Sir Huddibras, an hardy man;
And winnes an Oliue girlond for her meeds:
And inly grieue, as doth an hidden moth
An yearely solemne feast she wontes to make
The Miser threw him selfe, as an Offall,
Withouten sword or shield, an host to quaile?
Thereon an yron lock did fasten firme and strong.
And both his feet in fetters to an yron racke.
Vnto an aged woman, poore and bare,
With nature, did an Arber greene dispred,
He, like an Adder, lurking in the weeds,
And come vnto an Island, waste and voyd,
An armed knight, that towards him fast ran,
Lo, to that shore one in an auncient gowne,
An vncouth, saluage, and vnciuile wight,
And downe them poured through an hole full wide,
Fro me do flow into an ample flood,
Those be the riches fit for an aduent'rous knight.
It can puruay in twinckling of an eye;
That stretcht it selfe into an ample plaine,
The one in hand an yron whip did straine,
An vgly feend, more fowle then dismall day,
Like an huge caue, hewne out of rocky clift,
Till that they came vnto an yron dore,
Therein an hundred raunges weren pight,
In his right hand an yron club he held,
Like an huge Gyant of the Titans race,
And them beside an aged Sire did trace,
An armed knight, of bold and bounteous grace,
Whose squire bore after him an heben launce,
And deadly hew, an armed corse did lye,
An huge great paire of bellowes, which did styre
And therein sate an old old man, halfe blind,
An auncient booke, hight Briton moniments,
Where he an end of battell, and of life did make.
An happie man in his first dayes he was,
Enioyd an heritage of lasting peace,
And after all an army strong she leau'd,
An army brought, and with him battell fought,
With whom king Coyll made an agreement,
Were to those Pagans made an open pray,
Of life him selfe, and hart-strings of an ï¿½ fï¿½EUR gle riued.
Vpon his head he wore an Helmet light,
An huge great stone, which stood vpon one end,
An open passage through his riuen brest,
An hideous roaring farre away they heard,
And keepe an euen course; for yonder way
On th'other side an hideous Rocke is pight,
Therefore, Sir Palmer, keepe an euen hand;
Eftsoones they saw an hideous hoast arrayd,
At last they in an Island did espy
With the brode shadow of an hoarie hill,
On th'other side an high rocke toured still,
And did like an halfe Theatre fulfill:
Suddeinly an innumerable flight
Ere long they heard an hideous bellowing
Archt ouer head with an embracing vine,
The which into an ample lauer fell,
That had an hog beene late, hight Grille by name,
At last as through an open plaine they yode,
And him beside an aged Squire there rode,
Into an inner rowme, whose royaltee
When in so high an obiect they do lite,
Like an huge Aetn' of deepe engulfed griefe,
As it an Earth-quake were; at last she thus bespake.
And that old Dame said many an idle verse,
Making her seeke an vnknowne Paramoure,
It is an hideous hollow caue (they say)
But that he by an Elfe was gotten of a Fay.
And an huge hoste into Northumber lead,
How to effect so hard an enterprize,
And large of limbe, t'atchieue an hard emprize,
He tombled on an heape, and wallowd in his gore.
For gold, or perles, or pretious stones an howre,
This warlike sonne vnto an earthly peare,
An hundred knights of honorable name
But well I wote, that to an heauy hart
And fethered with an vnlucky quill;
And therewith shot an arrow at the lad;
As it an earthly Paradize had beene:
Through an vnwary dart, which did rebound
An huge eternall Chaos, which supplyes
Sore trouble of an hainous enimy;
Like as an Hynd forth singled from the heard,
To an hilles side, which did to her bewray
And doubted her to deeme an earthly wight,
An hideous beast, of horrible aspect,
But likest it to an Hyena was,
For which to God he made so many an idle boone.
An Egle, that with plumy wings doth sheare
She caught in hand an huge great yron mace,
Then it had lighted on an aged Oke;
The second was an holy Nunne to chose,
An armed knight, vpon a courser strong,
Hard is to teach an old horse amble trew.
An aged sire with head all frory hore,
Therein is eaten out an hollow caue,
As an immortall mote a mortall wight,
Vntill that it an issew forth may find;
Troy, that art now nought, but an idle name,
And with him led to sea an youthly trayne,
Into an Island spatious and brode,
Saue an huge nation of the Geaunts broode,
To proue some deedes of armes vpon an equall pere.
In lofty lookes to hide an humble mind,
Through many a wood, and many an vncouth way,
An hony combe, the wakefull dogs espy,
And nothing left, but like an aery Spright,
From an huge Geaunt, that with hideous
There an huge heape of singulfes did oppresse
Did raine into her lap an hony dew,
There was an Altar built of pretious stone,
On which there stood an Image all alone,
Faire heauen with an vniuersall cloud,
With that, an hideous storme of winde arose,
And an earth-quake, as if it streight would lose
An holy water Sprinckle, dipt in deowe,
Marcht in one rancke, yet an vnequall paire:
An angry Waspe th'one in a viall had
Th'other in hers an hony-lady Bee;
Now cease your worke; to morrow is an holy day.
Bring foorth an infinite increase, that breedes
Who rolled on an heape lay still in swound,
An hideous storme, is by the Northerne blast
The one a feend, the other an incarnate deuill.
Like an old Oke whose pith and sap is seare,
Let forth his wearie ghost and made an end of strife.
Strikes at an Heron with all his bodies sway,
To make an end of all that did withstand:
And in his head an hideous wound imprest:
They weened sure the warre was at an end,
Whereof full glad for thirst, ech drunk an harty draught.
For such an Hag, that seemed worse then nought,
Bearing that precious relicke in an arke
An huge great speare, such as he wont to wield,
That on an heape were tumbled horse and man.
When all vnwares he felt an hideous sway
An hundred knights had him enclosed round,
Into an heard, farre from the husband farme,
On Acidalian mount, where many an howre
And after these an hundred Ladies moe
An armed Knight vnder a forrest side,
But knowne by fame, and by an Hebene speare,
He in an open Turney lately held,
Did leape to her, as doth an eger hound
Thrust to an Hynd within some couert glade,
To lend an eare, and softly to relent.
Vpon an hard aduenture yet in quest,
An hardy hart, and his wide mouth did gape
She sent an arrow forth with mighty draught,
An happie life with grace and good accord,
Of time, did liue then like an innocent,
That them to view had bene an vncouth sight;
Of an huge Geauntesse whylome was bred;
An hard mishap and disauentrous case
